Literature Review: Inflammatory anemia is a complex condition characterized by the disruption of red blood cell (RBC) homeostasis due to the dysregulation of RBC production and clearance processes. This imbalance can lead to acute or chronic anemia, which can have severe consequences on tissue oxygenation and overall health. The immune system plays a crucial role in maintaining RBC homeostasis, and its dysregulation can contribute to the development of inflammatory anemia. In this review, we will discuss the common innate and adaptive immune mechanisms that contribute to inflammatory anemia, using examples from several diseases.Research has shown that inflammatory cytokines, such as TNF-α and IL-1β, can directly affect RBC production and clearance (1, 2). For instance, TNF-α has been shown to inhibit RBC production by suppressing the expression of erythropoietin receptors in the bone marrow (3). On the other hand, IL-1β can enhance RBC clearance by inducing the expression of hemophagocytic markers in macrophages (4). Furthermore, innate sensing pathways, such as the NLRP3 inflammasome, can also contribute to the development of inflammatory anemia by activating inflammatory cytokines and promoting RBC clearance (5).In diseases such as hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis/macrophage activation syndrome (HLH/MAS), the immune system is overactivated, leading to the excessive production of inflammatory cytokines and the activation of macrophages (6). This can result in the destruction of RBCs, leading to anemia. In severe malaria, the parasite Plasmodium falciparum can also contribute to anemia by inducing the production of inflammatory cytokines and the activation of macrophages (7). Similarly, in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), the immune system is characterized by the production of autoantibodies and the activation of immune cells, leading to the destruction of RBCs and the development of anemia (8).In addition to these mechanisms, other factors such as oxidative stress and inflammation can also contribute to the development of inflammatory anemia (9, 10). For example, oxidative stress can damage RBCs, leading to their premature destruction and the development of anemia. Inflammation can also exacerbate oxidative stress by promoting the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (11).In conclusion, inflammatory anemia is a complex condition characterized by the dysregulation of RBC production and clearance processes. The immune system plays a crucial role in maintaining RBC homeostasis, and its dysregulation can contribute to the development of inflammatory anemia. Understanding the common innate and adaptive immune mechanisms that contribute to inflammatory anemia is essential for the development of effective treatments for this condition.
